title: A shellshocked Bay Area reacts to Trump election with protests, tears and stunned silence
authors: Katy Murphy, Thomas Peele, Tatiana Sanchez, East Bay Times, Writing About Uc
content:
Dumbfounded , depressed and scared , left-leaning Californians awoke Wednesday to news that few saw coming : Donald Trump , not Hillary Clinton , would succeed Barack Obama in the White House .
“ It feels like a dream , ” Aubrey Patterson , 23 , said from behind the counter at a downtown Oakland coffee shop .
Across the Bay Area , students chanting “ not our president ” marched out of high schools in protest . Talk of secession — # calexit — trended on Twitter . Universities , churches and immigration advocates reached out to calm anxieties and offer support .
But like it or not , in January Trump will be the nation ’ s 45th president , an outcome the polls failed to predict and the liberal state of California — and its Bay Area bubble — didn ’ t fathom would ever come to pass .
California was second only to Hawaii in its share of support for Clinton — with about 62 percent voting for her . But while the race was never in doubt in the ultrablue Golden State , the reckoning was universal on Wednesday .
“ Are we so out of touch as Californians with the rest of the country ? ” said the Rev . Jayson Landeza , pastor of St. Benedict , a Catholic church in East Oakland .
An exit poll conducted for The Associated Press found that nationally , about one-third of voters were non-college-educated whites , and they flocked to Trump . But in California , that group represents only about 19 percent of the electorate .
Even the state ’ s top legislative leaders wrote Wednesday that they “ woke up feeling like strangers in a foreign land . ”
“ Yesterday Americans expressed their views on a pluralistic and democratic society that are clearly inconsistent with the values of the people of California , ” wrote Senate President Pro Tempore Kevin de León , D-Los Angeles , and California Assembly Speaker Anthony Rendon , D-Paramount .
Oakland ’ s downtown was alight with dumpster fires early Wednesday morning and Wednesday night , when police used incendiary devices to try and disperse thousands of protesters .
But much of the reaction elsewhere was somber and muted .
A universalist church in Hayward offered its congregants “ a contemplative candle light service , hugs , and hot chocolate ” to cope . At Argonne Elementary School in San Francisco , parents and kids hugged on the playground while half-seriously plotting moves to Costa Rica and New Zealand . Parents and teachers fretted on Facebook about how to talk to kids about Trump ’ s victory and how to make them feel safe .
The election of a candidate who promised mass deportations and a wall between the U.S. and Mexico triggered widespread panic among immigrants , from millennials who gained temporary legal status under the Obama administration ’ s executive order for childhood arrivals , or DACA , to parents who have U.S.-born children but are at risk of deportation .
“ I ’ m angry . I ’ m sad . And fearful for my community , ” said Eunice Hernandez , a 31-year-old organizer with the Sacred Heart Community Center in San Jose , breaking down as she spoke on Wednesday morning .
Jehan Hakim , a Muslim-American mother and civil rights advocate from Hayward , said she worries about anti-Muslim bullying worsening in schools and elsewhere . She knows of women who have already stopped wearing their headscarves since the election , fearing backlash .
And sexual assault prevention advocates such as Stanford Law professor Michele Dauber were in disbelief that so many Americans lined up behind a man caught on tape boasting about kissing and groping women without their consent .
“ Obviously we can ’ t look to the federal government to defend against sexual violence in our schools , ” she said .
University of California President Janet Napolitano and campus chancellors sent out a message assuring those “ feeling understandable consternation and uncertainty ” that UC would remain a welcoming environment that prized diversity . Stanford sent its own message offering counseling and other support to ease “ uncertainty , anger , anxiety and/or fear following yesterday ’ s election . ”
Warriors superstar Stephen Curry waded into the election ’ s emotional aftermath , tweeting that he had “ nothing but respect ” for Van Jones , an African-American CNN commentator who called Trump ’ s election a “ whitelash . ”
Students held mass demonstrations at Berkeley High School , Richmond High School , Albany High School , San Jose ’ s Lincoln High School , Oakland ’ s Bishop O ’ Dowd High School , Oakland School for the Arts and Oakland International High . San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick retweeted photos of some of the events on Twitter .
“ It ’ s like the country is going back to the 1800s , ” said 16-year-old Judy Cordova , outside of Oakland Technical High School , where hundreds left class Wednesday morning .
But not everyone woke up depressed . More than 290,000 voters in the five-county Bay Area cast a ballot for Trump . Pierre Casabonne Jr. , a general contractor from Walnut Creek , was one of them .
“ I felt awesome this morning , ” he said . “ It felt like we were a new country , like it was 1776 . It felt like a war had just been won in our country , and we took our country back — not just from the Democrats but from the politicians . ”
In the shadow of the Shell refinery outside Martinez , several Trump supporters gathered at a taco truck , celebrating the election results .
“ I don ’ t think we need a bully , but America needs to have a bigger backbone , and I think Trump ’ s got what it takes to do it , ” said Phil Bryan , of Martinez , who nonetheless wishes Trump would “ think before he speaks ” more often .
But across the Bay Area , Trump ’ s victory left Kashina Lee stunned and almost speechless . The 41-year-old African-American mother from Santa Clara said she even debated Wednesday whether it was safe to send her 5-year-old to school .
“ It sounds extreme , ” she said , “ but recently I have seen so many hateful racist people seem to come out of the woodwork to verbally and physically assault people of color . ”
As the election results rolled in , so did the calls and texts to the Rev . Jon Pedigo , from the Diocese of San Jose . Many were from families like Erica Leyva ’ s , worried about deportation .
Leyva didn ’ t sleep much Tuesday night . Although the 22-year-old and her two siblings were born in the U.S. , she said , they worry their parents will be forced to return to Mexico .
“ We are not broken . We are strong and resilient , ” she said . “ We need to stand up for our parents and our community . ”
